bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, August 16, 1949

div1.p: Hench explains to Kean and Truby that he has been so occupied with cortisone research that he has had no time for his Reed project. He has accepted the position of chairman of a research committee on rheumatic diseases.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean and Albert E. Truby, August 16, 1949
div1.opener:
XF
August 16, 1949
Generals Jefferson R. Kean and
Albert E. Truby
My dear Friends:
div1.p:
Much has happened to me since I last wrote you. Our International
Congress was an extremely busy event for me but was a most successful affair.
For the third time I gave our paper and we received another wonderful ovation.
Immediately after our paper five rheumatologists from all over the country, to
whom had been given enough cortisone (Compound E) to treat at least one or two
patients, rose one by one and confirmed our work. Nevertheless there is much
to be done so that we can learn how to use it properly even after the supply
is adequate.

We were simply amazed by the widespread interest in our work. I had
to under-go, with Doctor Kendall at the Congress, a press conference of 25
newspaper writers, reporters and science writers. Several of these people
got our reprints and with these plus the questions they asked at the conference,
they went out and wrote articles about our work which you may be seeing from
time to time. There was one in the July 23rd Saturday Evening Post, one in
the current issue of the Ladies' Home Journal, two in Canadian magazines and
a forthcoming one in the Woman's Home Companion, I understand.

I feel a great obligation to you two close friends because this will
explain in part what I have been doing and why I have had to, from time to time,
make my hobby subsidiary to my real job. Doctors Kendall and I have been very
pleased to receive word that we are to be given a Lasker Award for 1949. I don't
know much about this award but it seems to be one of the better American scien-
tific awards.

After our International Congress, of which I was General Chairman,
and which kept me extremely busy, I hurried home to get ready for 70 European
visitors on the Post-Convention Tour. As soon as they had left, (we demon-
strated Compound E to them, showing them on Monday morning an untreated patient,
letting them examine the patient, treating the patient and then demonstrating
again just two days later; they were quite impressed) I went east to a committee
meeting regarding Compound E and immediately on my return “blew a fuse” which
my wife had been expecting me to do for many months, and developed a moderately
severe intestinal hemorrhage from an unsuspected duodenal ulcer. I have been put
to bed, in and out of the hospital and confined to the house, dictating an hour
a day. I am much better; however I have been ordered to rest for two months and
am taking the whole family to the Hotel Broadmoor at Colorado Springs for three
weeks or so. I will return in mid-September.

I have had two recent letters from Johnny Moran. He has interested
himself in some movement for Miss Maas. By the way, Doctor Nogueira was at the
International Congress. I am sorry, General Truby, that your son did not meet
either Johnny Moran or Nogueira in Cuba. I do hope that he got around to see
Camp Lazear. It would be tragic if he did not.

The Surgeon General of the U.S. Public Health Service asked me to
be chairman of a research committee on rheumatic disease. I accepted. This
will carry me to Washington probably two or three times a year. The first
meeting is September 20 which I may have to miss but, General Kean, I shall be
going to New York City to receive the Lasker Award on October 25 and then speak
in Philadelphia October 31. (I have received over 40 invitations to speak during
the next few weeks, some very wonderful ones but I am turning them all down
except those above mentioned.)

Is there any chance that the Walter Reed Memorial Association meeting
could be arranged for near November 1? I doubt if it would be wise for me to
return to Washington three weeks later. Of course they can hold the meeting
without me just as well.

I received recently a letter from Blossom Reed. Her mother almost
died some weeks or months ago but again recovered. Blossom asked rather
anxiously whether, after her mother's death, the fund would be made available
to her. In answering, I could of course make no promises nor could I dis-
tinguish between the two children, Blossom and Laurence, but I did say that I
was sure that the Walter Reed Memorial Association would consider the care of
Walter Reed's children much more important than the erection of any memorial
at this time.

I have been asked to speak at the A.M.A. in San Francisco next
spring and have accepted, so that I will be seeing both of you within the
next few months.
